138.title: Conference closing and contest winners announcements
138.description: Make sure you won't miss closing ceremony, all gifts from out sponsors and partners will find their owners during this session.

137.title: Afterparty & Networking
137.description: Afterparty is a great time to have some fun and meet new people

136.title: GDG DevFest Hamburg 2016 Opening
136.description: Official start of the conference. Greetings from the organizers, sponsors and partners.

132.title: Registration & morning Coffee
132.description: Get your badge, coffee, enjoy talking with tech edicts around

121.title: The Bleeding Edge of Android Development
121.description: We all developers have experience the trending of a new technology, to be "mainstream" for using something that every other developer uses. We all have discovered some lib or technology that changed our mindset and wanted to use it everywhere, everytime. But all of that doesn't mean that we have to radically change how we work.

120.title: Hands on Kubernetes
120.description: Learn how to deploy a "dockerized" web application with Kubernetes

119.title: Best of ES6
119.description:
ES6 is among us now and it introduced many new useful features, which makes solving typical everyday JavaScript challenges a lot easier. Let’s go through real life examples to create code that is dynamic, robust and maintainable.
Warning: This talk may contain traces of Arrow Functions, Template Strings, Destructuring, Proxies, Generators, Iterables, Classes, Promises, Sets, Maps and Functional Programming.

118.title: The Physical Web: Prototyping the Internet of Things
118.description: It's no longer just about digitizing our environment. It’s rather about pervasive and ubiquitous computing. Almost all everyday things will turn into connected devices soon. This “Internet of Things” will allow the Web to be physically tangible. But what is the value, and how can one prevent IoT applications which just seem to be only more expensive and complicated than conventional solutions. Sascha will discuss the purpose and guide you through this complex topic showing inspiring solutions, tips from practice, and code samples in a variety of technologies from simple Bluetooth Eddystone Beacons to more sophisticated IoT platforms like Eclipse SmartHome in conjunction with augmented and virtual reality based on - yeah - Minecraft modding.

117.title: Mein Minecraft-Smart-Home
117.description: Vernetzte Alltagsgegenstände sind unaufhaltsam. Doch wie können wir die Generation Z darauf vorbereiten? Wie begeistern wir Kollegen oder die eigenen Kinder dafür, diese Zukunft verantwortungsbewusst mitzugestalten? Sascha und sein Sohn Jonathan nutzen dafür visuelle Programmierumgebungen wie Scratch und spielerische Programme in Minecraft. Und natürlich eignet sich diese Herangehensweise in Kombination mit Smart-Home-Lösungen wie openHAB oder QIVICON auch für professionelle Projekte.

116.title: Hands-on Web Performance Analysis with Chrome Dev Tools, Google PageSpeed Insights and WebPagetest
116.description:
We will use freely available tools like Chrome Dev Tools, Google PageSpeed Insights and WebPagetest as an introduction to the topic of Web Performance and Web Performance Optimization.

Using these tools we will inspect and analyze three given web sites. Furthermore we will discuss techniques to improve web perfomance on mobile devices and on the big screen.

115.title: Interact with Bluetooth devices on the Web
115.description: In a near future, one has not do download an App before connecting and controlling a physical device, but can simply visit a website. The WebBluetooth API specification is not yet a standard, but can be used via a flag in Chrome.  This talk will provide a deep dive into the WebBlutooth API and what can be done with it and where to use it right now.

114.title: Microservices in Google App Engine
114.description: Microservices is coming with a certain workload and constraints. Let's try to see how Google Cloud Platform and App Engine can help the overall microservices implementation.

113.title: Android Wear 2.0 Codelab
113.description: Android Wear 2.0 contains a number of exciting new features, such as Standalone apps, Material Design and new UI components, as well as support for complications. In this codelab, we will build a simple wearable application that can be run independently of a companion app on your phone and augment it with a complication data provider.

112.title: What's New in Android Wear 2.0
112.description: Android Wear 2.0 is a major update and contains a number of significant updates that will make it easier to build delightful experiences for wearables. In this session, I will provide an overview of new features such as Standalone apps, Material Design on Android Wear and some of the new UI components we're making available (such as Navigation Drawers and Action Drawers), as well as complications and complication data providers.

111.title: RxMVP with RxJava 2
111.description:
We'll talk about the upcoming release of RxJava 2 and how to use MVP in a reactive manner.
What we'll talk about:
- RxJava 1 (History, basic introduction)
- RxJava 2 (Reason / Motivation, What's new / What stayed)
- MVP with RxJava 2 + RxBinding

110.title: Illumination of density volumes with Neural Networks (Computergraphics)
110.description: Part of my masters thesis is, to find a possible way to illuminate density volumes, such as clouds, by using a deep-learning approach. I will talk about my current progress and possible solutions I came up with.

109.title: Progressive Web Apps
109.description:
The web of today and tomorrow has a ton of new features and APIs to offer, that will help creating mobile web pages that integrates well into your mobile or desktop system. Features like Service Workers make it possible to add a sophisticated offline support or background data synchronization to your web app. Also support for Push notifications will allow creating apps with rich notification and stay-up-to-date features.

This talk will use an example application to show and explain all the different techniques that play together to create today's Progressive Web Apps.

108.title: Level up your Gradle build
108.description: Gradle is an essential part of the daily life of an Android developer. For many developers it’s sufficient to just change some fields in the default build script and hit BUILD. But there is more beneath that. Learn how Gradle works and how you can gain more out of it by extending your build script with custom tasks and plugins.

107.title: Safe vs Deep integration of Realm
107.description:
Realm: A fast and secure database for Android, which is easy to learn and integrate.

Have you heard good things about Realm and considered replacing SQLite or ORM with Realm?
Do you know that with tons of advantages, Realm also brings some limitations?
Have you faced thread handling issues with Realm?
If yes, we will discuss different integration approaches of Realm and best practices to follow, along with RxJava, Retrofit, Dagger, Annotations & MVP.

In this talk, you will be learning:
1. What is Realm and why use it.
2. Safe vs Deep integration of Realm in Android, with examples.
3. Best practices to follow when using Realm, with examples.
4. Unit testing of Realm, with examples.

106.title: Record Meaningful UI Tests
106.description: Espresso Test Recording has been presented at this years Google I/O. As of Android Studio 2.2 preview 3 this feature has been available to the public. In this talk we will discover how to record tests and how to create highly readable and maintainable UI Tests from generated code. Furthermore we will discuss how to integrate the created Tests into BDD Frameworks like Cucumber.

105.title: The Art of Pushing
105.description:
A common component to a lot of apps is the capability to receive pushes and show notifications to the user. While many devs and product owners overlook them, considering them trivial, it is a vital component which requires a lot of caring to be done properly and can provide a competitive advantage.
In this talk we will address some common problems about push architecture and notification management, which implications have for the product and how to build a good UX around those while providing 4.0 to Android N support.

104.title: Zero to App: Develop with Firebase
104.description: Firebase helps mobile and web developers create extraordinary apps. It abstracts complex infrastructure and simplifies the development process. By using Firebase, developers can build the best user experience in the shortest amount of time, all without having to spin up servers or manage infrastructure. We explore how Firebase authenticates users and synchronizes data by creating an app on stage. You’ll experience first hand how easy it is to build with Firebase!

103.title: Virtual Reality in Android or Daydreaming about Cardboards
103.description:
On this year's IO Google announced Daydream, a new way of integrating your apps with Virtual Reality.
To prepare the audience for those new changes, I'll explain the current situation of the VR on Android by live coding two apps: An app using Unity to produce an App on Android and Ios, but also show how to write a simple photosphere app, written in pure Java, emphasising the differences and similarities between both SDKs.
After showing how to easily write Cardboard Apps, I'll introduce Daydream, and how this specification changes the usage of the SDK and how to use the simulated, or real controller.

102.title: Code-Build-Launch in Android N
102.description:
Android N contains a lot of major changes for both developers and users, but as developers we are mostly interested in coding, architecture etc. What new API's are added? Is there any deprecated class that I should not use? Why we didn't have java 8 for a very long time? Do we have it now? What is Jack? Is that a name?

In this talk, I’ll focus on these changes in detail and try to explain some concepts.

101.title: Connecting Microservices with gRPC
101.description: gRPC is a remote procedure call (RPC) framework developed at Google that allows you to define and consume services in a fast and lightweight way by using Protocol Buffers for binary serialization. gRPC is available in a wide variety of languages and platforms both for clients and servers. During this talk and codelab you’ll see why gRPC is important for today’s microservice architectures and a walk through a concrete example of two applications communicating via gRPC from a developer standpoint.
